inlineContent.text: Effects are returned from reducers so that the
can perform the effects after the
reducer is done running. It is important to note that
is not thread safe, and so all
effects must receive values on the same thread,
if the store is being used to drive UI
then it must receive values on the main thread.
value and provides some convenience initializers for
constructing some common types of effects.

abstract.text: The
type encapsulates a unit of work that can be run in the outside world, and can
feed data back to the
. It is the perfect place to do side effects, such as network
requests, saving/loading from disk, creating timers, interacting with dependencies, and more.
An effect that will cancel multiple currently in-flight effects with the given identifiers.
Throttles an effect so that it only publishes one output per given interval.
Creates an effect that executes some work in the real world that doesn’t need to feed data
back into the store. If an error is thrown, the effect will complete and the error will be ignored.
Returns an effect that will be executed after given
Initializes an effect from a callback that can send as many values as it wants, and can send
a completion.
Turns an effect into one that can be debounced.
Initializes an effect that immediately fails with the error passed in.
An effect that will cancel multiple currently in-flight effects with the given identifiers.
Turns an effect into one that can be debounced.
Initializes an effect that lazily executes some work in the real world and synchronously sends
that data back into the store.
Merges a sequence of effects together into a single effect, which runs the effects at the same
time.
Initializes an effect that lazily executes some work in the real world and synchronously sends
that data back into the store.
Transforms all elements from the upstream effect with a provided closure.
Throttles an effect so that it only publishes one output per given interval.
The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
Turns an effect into one that is capable of being canceled.
Turns an effect into one that is capable of being canceled.
Wraps the emission of each element with SwiftUI’s
A store represents the runtime that powers the application. It is the object that you will pass
around to views that need to interact with the application.
Returns an effect that repeatedly emits the current time of the given scheduler on the given
interval.
An effect that causes a test to fail if it runs.
Merges a variadic list of effects together into a single effect, which runs the effects at the
same time.
Initializes an effect that immediately emits the value passed in.
An effect that will cancel any currently in-flight effect with the given identifier.
Creates an effect that can supply a single value asynchronously in the future.
Wraps an asynchronous unit of work in an effect.
Wraps an asynchronous unit of work in an effect.
An effect that will cancel any currently in-flight effect with the given identifier.
Initializes an effect that wraps a publisher. Each emission of the wrapped publisher will be
emitted by the effect.
Concatenates a collection of effects together into a single effect, which runs the effects one
after the other.
The
type encapsulates a unit of work that can be run in the outside world, and can
feed data back to the
. It is the perfect place to do side effects, such as network
requests, saving/loading from disk, creating timers, interacting with dependencies, and more.
Creates an effect that executes some work in the real world that doesn’t need to feed data
back into the store. If an error is thrown, the effect will complete and the error will be ignored.
Concatenates a variadic list of effects together into a single effect, which runs the effects
one after the other.
An effect that does nothing and completes immediately. Useful for situations where you must
return an effect, but you don’t need to do anything.
Returns an effect that repeatedly emits the current time of the given scheduler on the given
interval.
